prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN-HNC-HC15N
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of the proposal is to determine the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio in the PDR around the ultracompact HII region Mon R2. To achieve this objective we need to map the region in the HCN 3-2, H13CN 3-2, HC15N 3-2, HNC 3-2 and HN13C 3-2 lines. All these line cannot be observed in a single spectral setup. For this reason we have divided the lines into two Science goals. In this first science goal, we propose to observe J=3-2 lines of H13CN, HNC and HC15N and in the second science goal, we will observe the same line of HN13C and HCN. To observe isotopologues with different abundances is necessary to derive accurate values of the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio for a wide range visual extinctions. Assuming the typical physical conditions of the molecular gas in Mon R2 (Tk=50 K n=4x10^5 cm-3) and a fractional abundance of 10^-9 for HCN and HNC, the requested sensitivity will allow us to derive the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio for Av between 2 to >200 mag.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: According to our 30m data, the observed spectra have two different velocity components, each one with a linewidth of around 1 km/s, and separated by 1-2 km/s. Therefore, we need a spectral resolution of 0.25 km/s and obtain 4 spectral elements in each velocity components, necessary to sample the line profile properly. In order to achieve this high velocity resolution, we have selected correlator configurations with velocity resolutions of around 0.13-0.15 km/s in the lines that are essential to achieve the immediate objectives of this science goal (H13CN, HC15N, HNC). We selected velocity resolutions of around 0.3 km/s for the second priority usually weaker lines.

Our H13CN 3-2 map shows that the emission is concentrated in clumps that remain unresolved with a 10-arcsec beam. Spitzer maps show that the thickness of the H2 emisison is of about 4 arcsec, with the H2 tracing the photon dominated region on the illuminated surface of the clumps. Therefore, we need an angular resolution of 1 arcsec to fully resolve the PDR and determine the spatial structure of the emission. The largest angular scale is the beam of the 30m telescope at this frequency. We plan to combine ALMA data with the 30m images to recover all spatial scales. We note that the sensitivity of the IRAM 30m maps is 100mK, which is good enough (compared to the proposed ALMA sensitivity of 150mK) to combine both datasets.

The main lines in this Science Goal for our Immediate Scientific Objectives are H13CN 3-2 and HNC 3-2. Out of the two lines, H13CN 3-2 is the weakest one and therefore the one that sets our sensitivity limits. In order to be conservative, we have used the intensity of the H13CN (3-2) line as observed with the IRAM 30m telescope at the IF position for our calculations. The intensity is 3 Jy/beam (in a 10-arcsec beam). Assuming a uniform distribution of the brightness temperature in the beam, we expect a flux of 30mJy in the proposed 1-arcsec beam observations. In order to obtain S/N of 4 in a 0.25-km/s channel (of 6 in 1/3 of the linewidth), we need a sensitivity of around 8 mJy (or 150 mK). It is worth mentioning that these estimates have been obtained by considering conservative assumptions and we expect stronger lines because: (i) The IF is located in a minimum of emission in our 30m map (see Fig. 1), and the intensity in some clumps is 10 times stronger; and (ii) we would also expect higher intensities of the H13CN 3-2 line in 1-arcsec beam if the emission is not distributed uniformly in the 30m beam but, as suggested by our map, comes from smaller clumps (this would imply that there is a certain beam dilution in the intensities measured with the 30m telescope). Therefore, we consider that a sensitivity of 150 mK is enough to have a good S/N map of the H13CN 3-2 line.

We have set a number of spectral windows to cover other interesting lines (SO, HC18O+, H29alpha, HC3N, l-C3H, c-C3H, N15NH+). If detected, these lines will help to determine the structure of the clumps and the PDR properties. It is worth metioning that the observation of three SO lines (these observations together with science goal 2) will allow to determine the physical conditions of the molecular gas. Carbon chains and N-species (l-C3H, c-C3H, HC3N, N15NH+) will help to constrain the HCN/HNC chemistry. Finally, the observation of HC18O+ and H29alpha will inform about the structure of the most external layers of the PDR. We note that we are above the standard data rate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN-HN13C-C2H
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of the proposal is to determine the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio in the PDR around the ultracompact HII region Mon R2. To achieve this objective we need to map the region in the HCN 3-2, H13CN 3-2, HC15N 3-2, HNC 3-2 and HN13C 3-2 lines. All these line cannot be observed in a single spectral setup. For this reason we have divided the lines into two Science goals. In this second science goal, we propose to observe the J=3-2 lines of HCN and HN13C. To observe isotopologues with different abundances is necessary to derive accurate values of the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio for a wide range of visual extinctions. Assuming the average physical conditions in Mon R2 (Tk=50 K, n=4x10^5 cm-3), and a typical fractional abundance of 10^-9 for HCN and HNC, the requested sensitivity will allow us to derive the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio from Av around 2 to >200 mag. In this setup, we also include the intense C2H 3-2 line. The comparison of the spatial distribution of C2H with those of HCN/HNC will provide valuable information on the chemical relation between these two families of carbon chains.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: According to our 30m data, the observed spectra show two velocity components, each with a linewidth of around 1 km/s and separated by 1-2 km/s. We need a spectral resolution of 0.25 km/s to obtain 4 spectral elements in each velocity components, necessary to sample the line profile properly. To achieve this resolution, we have selected resolution elements of 0.13-0.15 km/s for the essential lines in this Science Goal, i.e., HN13C, HCN and C2H. For the second prioritaty lines, we have selected resolution elements of about 0.3 km/s.

As discussed in Science Goal 1, the HN13C emission is expected to come from clumps that remain unresolved with the 10-arcsec 30m beam. At the same time, Spitzer maps show that the thickness of the H2 emission is about 4 arsec, with H2 tracing the PDR on the illuminated surface of the clumps. Therfore we need an angular resolution of 1-arcsec to fully resolve the PDR and the structure of the clumps. The largest angular scale is the beam of the 30m telescope at this frequency.

The main lines in this Science Goal for our Immediate objectives are HN13C 3-2, HCN 3-2 and CCH 3-2. Out of the three lines, HN13C 3-2 is the weakest one and therefore the one that sets out sensitivity limits. We assume that in the interior of the high density clumps the Tb(H13CN 3-2)/Tb(HN13C 3-2) ratio is close to 1. For this reason we use the same rms and spectral resolution as in Science Goal 1: 150 mK (8mJy) per 0.25 km/s channel to achieve a S/N of 4. In the illuminated surface of the clump where the Tb(H13CN 3-2)/Tb(HN13C 3-2) could be as high as 10, we do not expect to detect the HN13C 3-2 emission but expect the HNC 3-2 line (observed in Science Goal 1) be optically thin and usable to calculate the HCN/HNC ratio.

We have set spectral windows to observe some interesting lines (SO, c-C3H2, C3H+). As discussed in Science goal 1, the SO lines are going to be used to determine the physical conditions of the molecular gas. The small hydrocarbons c-C3H2 and C3H+, are good tracers of the PDR and their chemistry is related to that of HCN and HNC. Their observation will help for the best understanding of the carbon and nitrogen chemistries.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The two isomers of the H-C-N system, hydrogen cyanide (HCN) and hydrogen isocyanide (HNC), are commonly used as tracers of the dense molecular gas in Galactic and extra-galactic research. Moreover, the [HCN]/[HNC] is considered as a chemical diagnostic for the gas temperature. The full comprehension of the HCN and HNC chemistry is therefore of paramount importance in the study of the physics and chemistry of the interstellar gas. In the latest years, gas phase and gas-grain chemical models have increased in complexity and incorporated new laboratory measurements to provide an accurate and complete description of their chemistry. However, high spatial resolution and high sensitivity data are needed to test these models. Based on our IRAM 30m 2D spectral survey, we have measured an anomalously high [HCN]/[HNC] ratio (larger than 10) towards the ultracompact HII region Mon R2. Time dependent effects and photodesorption have been proposed as possible explanations. Our goal is to determine the [HCN]/[HNC] ratio at a spatial resolution of 1-arcsec in order to discern between these two interpretations and investigate the influence of UV photons on the chemistry of the H-C-N system.
